questions.text: The autopsy of a 60-year-old man who died of a respiratory illness revealed the following findings on the pleura. What was the most likely occupation of this man?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing pleural plaques are suggestive of asbestosis. Asbestosis develops due to prolonged inhalation of asbestos, which is common in the insulation industry. 

Pleural plaques are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They are well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen, often containing calcium. They develop most frequently on the parietal pleura and over the domes of the diaphragm. They do not contain asbestos bodies, and only rarely occur in persons without prior asbestos exposure.

Asbestos occurs in two distinct forms - serpentine chrysotile (more common) and amphibole (more pathogenic). Exposure may result in the following conditions:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or, rarely, diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Pleural effusions
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Extrapulmonary neoplasms including laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

The image below shows fibrous pleural plaques seen on the diaphragmatic pleural surface in asbestosis.

Other options-

Option B: Anthracosis/coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. The inhaled carbon pigment is engulfed by alveolar or interstitial macrophages, which accumulate in the connective tissue. On prolonged exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis, which is called complicated coal workers' pneumoconiosis. The upper lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis. 

The image below shows anthracosis—black pigment engulfed within macrophages as well as in the form of deposits.

Option C: Silicosis is due to the inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in sandblasting or rock mining. Macrophages phagocytose inhaled silica particles, thereby activating and releasing inflammatory mediators, like IL-1 and IL-8.

Histopathology reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages. Radiologically, egg-shell calcification of the lymph nodes is seen.

Shown below is an image of a silicotic nodule with collagen whorls as seen in this condition.

Option D: Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of bagasse or sugarcane dust. A thermophilic actinomycete, Thermoactinomyces sacchari is the causative organism/ The symptoms are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, and fever. Initially, it can result in acute diffuse bronchiolitis. If left untreated it can progress to diffuse fibrosis, emphysema, and bronchiectasis.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman presents with complaints of yellowish discoloration of the skin for 1 week and severe fatigue. On examination, you notice her to have tachycardia, pallor, icterus, and splenomegaly. Her investigation reports are shown below. What is the underlying mechanism for this presentation?

Serum hemoglobin- 6g/dL
Coomb’s test- positive
Serum LDH - elevated
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation indicates hemolysis and a positive Coomb's test suggests autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The underlying mechanism of this condition is type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Since in autoimmune hemolytic anemia, antibodies recognize red cells and cause their premature destruction via opsonization, it is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Elevated LDH indicates hemolysis and a positive Coomb's test is indicative of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The presentation is usually dramatic with abrupt onset anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: An elderly man presented with language deficits, loss of mathematical skills and motor skills. His family reports that his symptoms began many years ago with forgetfulness and memory disturbances. He is now apathetic, withdrawn, agitated, and is prone to wandering. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an elderly male with forgetfulness, memory disturbances, language deficits, loss of mathematical skills and motor skills, apathy, withdrawal, agitation, and wandering is likely to have Alzheimer's disease. Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex is seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. 

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. Its incidence increases with age. It has an insidious onset with deficits developing over the course of 5-10 years. Initially, the patient presents with forgetfulness but then progresses to language deficits, loss of mathematical skills, and motor skills. In the end stages, the patient becomes mute, incontinent, unable to walk. They usually develop pneumonia. 

The pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease involves the accumulation of Aβ amyloid and tau in the brain. The hallmarks of this condition are amyloid plaques comprised of aggregated Aβ amyloid and neurofibrillary tangles. Neurofibrillary tangles are the cytoplasmic accumulation of tau filaments. Neuritic plaques are focal collections of axonal or dendritic processes around a central amyloid core. In pyramidal neurons, they appear as flame-shaped. These lesions lead to neuronal death. 

On gross examination, the brain shows cortical atrophy which can be seen with gyral narrowing and sulcal widening in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes. This will lead to compensatory enlargement of the ventricles. 

The following image shows the neurofibrillary tangles seen in Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman, previously diagnosed with breast cancer, is now found to have endometrial cancer. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the PTEN gene. What other condition is she at increased risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A patient with a PTEN germline mutation with history of breast carcinoma, now diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is at high risk of developing thyroid carcinoma concerning cowden syndrome.

Cowden syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with pTEN germline mutations and marked by:

  • Hamartomatous growths of the skin and mucus membranes- buccal, intestinal, and colonic
  • Increased incidence of epithelial cancers particularly of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, which is worse during menstruation. Laparoscopic examination of the pelvis demonstrates multiple small brown spots on the surface of pelvic structures and extensive fibrous adhesions between tubes, ovaries, and other structures. A biopsy is done and microscopy is as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows glands resembling endometrial glands surrounded by endometrial stroma in the ovary. The most likely diagnosis is endometriosis. 

Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. Includes both endometrial glands and stroma, but may consist only of stroma in some cases. 

It occurs in the following sites, in descending order of frequency

  • Ovaries
  • Uterine ligaments
  • Rectovaginal septum
  • Cul de sac
  • Pelvic peritoneum
  • Large and small bowel and appendix
  • Mucosa of the cervix, vagina, and fallopian tubes
  • Laparotomy scars.

It is principally a disease of women in active reproductive life, most often in the third and fourth decades. It causes infertility, dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation), pelvic pain, and other problems. Endometriotic lesions bleed periodically in response to both extrinsic cyclic (ovarian) and intrinsic hormonal stimulation.

The diagnosis is readily made when both endometrial glands and stroma are present with or without the presence of hemosiderin. In rare cases, only the stroma is identified.

Atypical endometriosis, the likely precursor to endometriosis-related ovarian carcinoma, has two morphologic appearances. One consists of cytologic atypia of the epithelium lining the endometriotic cyst without major architectural changes. The second is marked by glandular crowding due to excessive epithelial proliferation, often associated with cytologic atypia, producing an appearance that resembles complex atypical endometrial hyperplasia.

Other options

Option A- Adenomyosis is characterized by foci of the endometrium deep in the myometrium.

Option B- Chronic endometritis is a chronic inflammation of the endometrium.

Option C- Metastatic endometrial carcinoma would be characterized by abnormal glands and cytologic atypia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man developed nausea and jaundice over the past week. Laboratory investigations revealed an active hepatitis B infection. Which of the following liver pathology findings is depicted in the slide below?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman's bodies and they represent apoptosis.

Councilman's bodies are acidophilic bodies, which represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis. They are mainly seen in acute viral hepatitis.

Apoptosis is a pathway of cell death that is induced by a closely regulated suicide program in which the cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells' nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. 

Mechanism of apoptosis: There are two distinct pathways that can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell.

  • The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway
  • The death receptor or extrinsic pathway

The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • There are several proteins in the mitochondria that can induce apoptosis. These include cytochrome c and some proteins that neutralize the endogenous inhibitors of apoptosis.
  • The permeability of the mitochondria is controlled by a family of proteins called the BCL-2 family, which act as sensors.
  • These sensors are activated when the cells are deprived of growth factors and other survival signals, are exposed to agents that damage the DNA, or accumulate a large number of misfolded proteins.
  • These activated sensors, in turn, activate the proapoptotic molecules like BAX and BAK, which form channels in the mitochondrial membrane, through which cytochrome c and other mitochondrial proteins escape into the cytosol and cause activation of caspase-9, which, in turn, leads to the activation of the caspase cascade and, eventually, apoptosis of the cell.
  • On the other hand, if all the growth factors and other survival signals are present, then they produce more antiapoptotic members of the BH1-4 family like the BCL2, MCL 1, and BCL-XL. These proteins limit the escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

The death-receptor (extrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • Death receptors are surface molecules that are members of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) receptor family, like TNF 1 and Fas (CD 95).
  • These receptors are expressed on the surface of many cells and can trigger apoptosis. In the cytoplasmic region, these receptors have a “death domain.”
  • Fas ligand (FasL) is a membrane protein expressed mainly on activated T-lymphocytes. Fas-FasL interactions are required for thymic medullary negative selection. Defective interactions also cause the autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. 
  • When these T-cells recognize Fas-expressing targets, Fas molecules are cross-linked by FasL and bind adaptor proteins via the death domain.
  • These, in turn, recruit and activate caspase-8 and -10.
  • In many cell types, caspase-8 and -10 may cleave and activate a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family called Bid, thus feeding into the mitochondrial pathway.
  • The combined activation of both pathways delivers a lethal blow to the cell.
  • Cellular proteins, notably, a caspase antagonist called FLIP, block the activation of caspases downstream of the death receptors. Interestingly, some viruses produce homologues of FLIP, and it is suggested that this is a mechanism that viruses use to keep infected cells alive.
  • The death receptor pathway is involved in the elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes and in the killing of target cells by some cytotoxic T-lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and a rash on her face, as seen below. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are positive. Which of the following is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and image is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). C1, C2, and C4 complements are deficient in SLE patients.

The rash seen in the image is a malar rash (classically seen in SLE); it is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences, with sparing of the nasolabial folds. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are specific for SLE.

Clinical syndromes associated with genetic deficiencies of various complement components:

  • C1 inhibitor deficiency - Hereditary angioedema
  • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - SLE and other collagen vascular disorders
  • C5-C8 deficiency - Toxoplasmosis, bacteremia with gram-negative diplococci 
  • C3 and its regulatory protein or C3b inactivator deficiency - Severe recurrent pyogenic infections

questions.text:
You perform an autopsy of a 25-year-old male who suffered a sudden cardiac death and notice the chambers of the heart to be enlarged. You suspect the cause of death to be dilated cardiomyopathy. What can be a likely cause of this condition?

i)Titin mutation

ii)Dystrophin mutation

iii)Myosin binding protein C mutation

iv)Hemochromatosis

v)Alcohol intake
questions.solution:
Titin mutation, dystrophin mutation, hemochromatosis and alcohol intoxication can all lead to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy and thus are a likely cause of this condition- option (c) is the correct answer.

Mutation of myosin binding protein C is the most common cause of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy not dilated cardiomyopathy thus is not a likely cause of this condition. 

Causes of Dilated cardiomyopathy

    1. Familial (50%)- mutation of genes encoding proteins of cytoskeleton, sarcolemma and nuclear envelope
      1. TTN gene mutation encoding titin protein
      2. Dystrophin gene mutation - associated with skeletal myopathies ( Duchenne muscular dystrophy etc)
    2. Alcohol intake
      1. Ethanol toxicity
      2. Chronic intake -> thiamine deficiency -> beriberi heart disease ( dilated cardiomyopathy)
    3. Iron overload
      1. Hemochromatosis
      2. Multiple blood transfusions
    4. Viral myocarditis
    5. Peripartum cardiomyopathy
    6. Cobalt toxicity

questions.text: An 82-year-old male patient dies of severe congestive heart failure. An autopsy was done, which revealed the following appearance of the aortic valve. Blood investigations done before death revealed normal levels of serum sodium, potassium, calcium, and chloride. Which of the following pathological processes is likely to have resulted in the appearance of the aortic valve as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows extensive calcification of the aortic valve resulting in stenosis. Calcification of the valve, in an elderly patient, with normal serum calcium levels, occurs due to dystrophic calcification.

When the deposition of calcium occurs in dead or dying tissues, it is called dystrophic calcification. This occurs in the absence of derangements in calcium metabolism, i.e. the calcium levels are normal. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type including coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive, and in foci of enzymatic fat necrosis.

Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis. It also commonly develops in aging or damaged heart valves.

Other options:

Option A - Cardiac amyloidosis may occur secondary to systemic amyloidosis or as a result of aging (senile amyloidosis). It is associated with the deposition of hyaline, eosinophilic amyloid, in the conduction tissue, interstitium, and coronary vessels. These deposits may be seen on Congo red staining.

Option B - Monckeberg medial sclerosis is a vascular pathology of aging characterized by calcifications accumulating in the medial layers of muscular arteries. Since there is no vascular compromise (no luminal narrowing), it is usually an accidental finding.

Option D - Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues, in the presence of hypercalcemia. It is usually a consequence of excessive parathyroid hormone.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a chronic history of heartburn. An upper GI endoscopy was done, and a biopsy from a suspicious lesion showed the following picture. Identify the condition and the special stain used to confirm the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and histology findings are suggestive of Barrett's esophagus, and mucin stain (Alcian blue) is used to identify goblet cells, which are indicative of the intestinal metaplasia occurring in the condition.

Barrett's esophagus is a type of metaplasia at the gastro-esophagal junction due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The squamous esophageal mucosa is converted to a columnal/intestinal type that is better suited to handle acid reflux. It is associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Grossly it appears as tongues of red, velvety mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction. This metaplastic mucosa alternates with residual smooth, pale squamous (esophageal) mucosa. Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett's esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.

Alcian blue staining of mucin in Barrett's mucosa is shown in the image given below:

Other options:

Option A: Helicobacter pylori infection can be diagnosed with Warthin-Starry silver stain. It can also present with heartburn, but histology would show organisms within the surface mucus and inflammatory cell infiltrate below the epithelium in the antrum and not a columnar esophagus.

Option B: Barrett's esophagus and long-standing GERD can result in adenocarcinoma of distal esophagus. It would show increased intestinal-type glands with features of carcinoma.

Option D: Squamous cell carcinoma commonly occurs in the middle esophagus, and a well-differentiated tumor would show intercellular bridges and nests of keratin pearls.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with oliguria, haematuria, and pedal edema over the past 3 days. He complains that his symptoms worsened rapidly. On examination, he has a BP of 190/140 mmHg. Blood workup shows elevated serum creatinine and blood urea. Histological studies show crescents in the glomeruli as seen in the image below. Which of the following type of nephritis does the clinical scenario suggest?
questions.solution:
The rapidly worsening symptoms and the histologic picture are suggestive of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) also known as crescentic glomerulonephritis. 

It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents. The disease progresses rapidly and leads to renal failure in weeks to months when not treated. In the majority of the cases, RPGN is immune-mediated. In pauci-immune type of RPGN, circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are detected in most cases. Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes.

Other options:

Option B: Minimal change disease - presence of difuse effacement of podocytes (epithelial cell foot process) which is characteristic. It is one of the common causes of nephrotic syndrome. However, this glomerular abnormality can only be detected using electron microscopy and appear normal by light microscopy. 

Option C: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis - presence of focal and segmental scarring of the glomeruli most prominently seen at the corticomedullary junction.

Option D: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis - presence of thickenend glomerular basement membrane with mesangioproliferation and are of three types where type 1 is associated with hepatitis C infection while type 2 and 3 are idiopathic or complement mediated.

questions.text: The genetic testing of a 2-year-old boy presenting with an abdominal mass and other congenital anomalies revealed deletion of WT1 and PAX6 genes. Which of the following features is seen in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
WT1 and PAX6 gene deletion results in WAGR syndrome. This syndrome leads to intellectual disability.

The components of WAGR syndrome are 

  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genitourinary abnormalities
  • Intellectual disability

PAX6 deletion alone increases the risk of developing aniridia, and WT1 deletion increases the risk of developing Wilms tumor. However, both of these genes are located on chromosome 11p13. Thus, deletion of 11p13 leads to the deletion of both genes, leading to the development of WAGR syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with dark urine, fatigue and jaundice following the use of antimalarials. The peripheral blood smear shows cells as in the image below. All of the following findings can be seen in the patient except
questions.solution:
The patient’s peripheral blood smear shows bite cells characteristic of G6PD deficiency, likely precipitated after the use of antimalarials in this case. A positive direct Coomb’s test is unlikely in G6PD deficiency; it is seen in autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder, in which the patient is usually asymptomatic unless challenged by oxidative agents such as fava beans, infections, and certain drugs leading to episodes of hemolytic anemia. 

Intravascular hemolysis in G6PD deficiency leads to normocytic normochromic anemia (causes fatigue), hemoglobinemia, hemoglobinuria (causes dark-colored urine), elevated LDH, absent/low haptoglobin (options b, c, d).

A blood smear may show Blister or bite cells and Heinz inclusion bodies (denatured hemoglobin within RBC):

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging midline neck swelling, along with hoarseness of voice and dyspnea. The histopathological study of the biopsy is given below. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathology slide showing sheets of undifferentiated, anaplastic cells with marked cytologic atypia, are likely suggestive of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a rare and one of the most aggressive malignancies in humans. It is usually diagnosed in the elderly and there is a female preponderance. The clinical features include rapidly enlarging neck mass, dysphagia, hoarseness, cough, and hemoptysis. Patients have distant metastasis at the time of presentation and the most common sites include lungs, bone, and brain.

Management of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma (ATC) is as follows:

  • Total thyroidectomy with central node dissection is the recommended surgery.
  • En bloc resection- if an extrathyroidal extension is present.
  • Postoperative external beam irradiation or adjunctive chemotherapy (adriamycin + paclitaxel/cisplatin) is given to prolong survival.

Other options:

Option B: Follicular thyroid carcinoma shows uniform cells forming small follicles and they are filled with colloid and normal thyroid tissue. The below image shows follicular thyroid carcinoma.

Option C: Medullary carcinoma has polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests or trabeculae and contains amyloid deposits in the stroma. The below image shows medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Option D: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is characterised by branching papillae, orphan Annie eye nuclei are nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and psammoma bodies that are concentric calcified structures within the papillae. They are shown below in the image.

Related Pearl: AJCC 8th edition Changes in the TNM staging of Thyroid neoplasms:

Differentiated Thyroid Cancer:

  • The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. 
  • Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.
  • N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If ≥ 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.
  • T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland
  • T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)
  • Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.
  • In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer continues to be classified as IVC disease.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the right knee for the past few months. On examination, there is tenderness in the affected part with a reduced range of motion. A radiographic study revealed a solitary lytic lesion at the distal end of the femur and the microscopic appearance of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is not an x-ray finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and microscopic appearance are suggestive of osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor and they are purely radiolucent.

Microscopically they are composed of mononuclear cells with macrophages. They are more common between the age of 20-40 and typically affect the metaphyses of long bones with a preponderance for the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius and proximal humerus.

Important X-ray features of a GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly lobulated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

 

 

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like distal ulna, clavicle, proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man had multiple nodular skin lesions for the past 5 years. Previous investigations showed CD 4 T helper cells in these lesions. He has been using topical steroids for its management. He now presents with rapid onset diffuse erythema of the skin. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased CD 8 T cells in the skin
Abnormal T cells with cerebriform nucleus in blood
Increased mast cells around dermal blood vessels

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the development of Sezary syndrome in a patient with mycosis fungoides. This syndrome shows the presence of abnormal T cells with cerebriform nucleii (Sezary cells) in the blood.

Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CD4+ Helper T cells) which usually stays confined to the skin. It can disseminate into blood which is known as Sezary syndrome. It presents as diffuse erythema of the skin (erythroderma).

Mycoses fungoides presents as scaly red-brown patches, raised scaling plaques, and fungating nodules. It passes through 3 phases:

  • Inflammatory pre-mycotic phase- eczema like lesions
  • Plaque phase- raised plaques are seen
  • Tumor phase- multiple tumor nodules indicating systemic spread

The given image shows mycosis fungoides:

Sezary syndrome occurs when malignant T cells from mycoses fungoides are seeded into blood. This leads to diffuse erythema and scaling of the entire body surface. The skin lesions in case of Sezary syndrome rarely reach tumefaction phase.

The given image shows erythrodermic sezary syndrome:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of easy fatigability, weight loss, and an evening rise in temperature. Investigations reveal pancytopenia. The bone marrow aspirate of a patient is shown in the image given below. Cytogenetic studies revealed the presence of t(15:17). This subtype of disease is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of Auer rods on bone marrow aspirates and t(15:17) on cytogenic studies points towards the diagnosis of AML-M3. DIC is most commonly associated with AML-M3.

Peripheral smear (WBC):

1) Acute myeloid leukemia

Acute myeloid leukemia is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations. This leads to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow resulting in marrow failure and complications related to anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia.

  • Bone marrow/peripheral smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow). It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods: Needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies(black arrow) particularly seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) with t(15;17).

 

2) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) 

ALL arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts. Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and scant basophilic cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

3) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)

CLL is associated with the deletions of 13q, 11q, 17q, and trisomy 12q. Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes with proliferation centers. The peripheral smear shows small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and smudge cells as seen below.

4) Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)

CML is characterized by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors. The image below shows peripheral smear findings of CML with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Other options

Option A: Chloroma( localised soft tissue mass composed of extramedullary proliferation of primitive cells of myeloid lineage) is commonly associated with AML-M2. It can also be seen in AML-M4 and M5

Option C: Leukemia cutis(leukemic infiltration of the epidermis, the dermis, and the subcutaneous tissue.). is associated with AML-M4 and M5.

Option D: Down's syndrome is associated with AML-M7.

questions.text: A young female patient was brought to the emergency room with severe gastrointestinal bleeding. The attenders inform the duty doctor that the patient was on warfarin medications. Her blood group is unknown. The duty doctor can transfuse fresh frozen plasma (FFP) from which of the following blood groups?
questions.solution:
AB fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is given when uncross-matched plasma is needed as in the above case, wherein the blood group of the patient is not known.

It is to be noted that in cases of active bleeding in a patient on warfarin therapy, prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is recommended over FFP. In case PCC is not available, FFP is used as in the above case.

FFP is plasma prepared from whole blood, either from the primary centrifugation of whole blood into red cells and plasma or from the secondary centrifugation of platelet-rich plasma. The plasma is rapidly frozen to –25°C or colder within 8 hours of collection and contains normal plasma levels of stable clotting factors, albumin, immunoglobulin, and Factor VIII at a level of at least 70% of normal fresh plasma.

Each unit of issued FFP contains a quantity of 200-300 mL.

FFP is capable of transmitting any agent present in cells or plasma, which was undetected by routine screening including HIV, hepatitis B and C, syphilis, and malaria.

Definite indications of FFP transfusion:

  • Replacement of a single coagulation factor deficiency, where a specific or combined factor concentrate is unavailable or contraindicated.
  • Immediate reversal of warfarin effect where prothrombin complex concentrate is unavailable.
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • Inherited coagulation inhibitor deficiencies where the specific concentrate is unavailable.
  • C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency where the specific concentrate is unavailable

In an emergency, if crossmatched blood is unavailable:

  • Type O negative pRBCs are indicated for patients with exsanguinating hemorrhage because it lacks the A and B and Rh antigens, and thus, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B, or anti-D antibodies in the recipient’s blood.
  • AB plasma is given when uncross-matched plasma is needed because it does not contain antibodies against any antigens on RBCs.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy has frequent episodes of facial edema around his lips. It usually occurs after an emotional stressor. He also has a family history of similar conditions. Which of the following is the main mediator of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hereditary angioedema. The main inflammatory mediator responsible for these symptoms is bradykinin.

Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator formed by the cleavage of kininogen, in the presence of the enzyme kallikrein. Bradykinin has the following effects:

  • Increases the vascular permeability
  • Causes contraction of smooth muscle
  • Dilates the blood vessel 
  • Mediates pain

Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, its deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein, leading to increased bradykinin.

Features of the condition include swelling of the skin and mucosal surfaces, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. They may be aggravated after minor trauma or emotional stressor. The condition can be treated by giving C1 inhibitor concentrates from human plasma. 

Option D: histamine is implicated as a mediator of angioedema in anaphylaxis. However, the main mediator in Heriditory Angioedema is bradykinnin and therefore the correct answer.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female patient is diagnosed with breast cancer. The findings of immunohistochemistry staining are shown in the image given below. Identify the subtype of breast cancer based on these findings.
questions.solution:
The above image shows immunohistochemistry staining positive for ER, PR, and HER2 receptors, which is triple positive or luminal type B of breast cancer.

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:
